DOC.HEAD: Eds: CORRECTS closing S&P 500 index to 343.77 in 16th graf.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market took its sharpest drop in five weeks Monday, hit by selling attributed to spreading worries about the real-estate outlook. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 42.02 to 2,697.53, for its biggest single-day loss since it dropped 47.34 points on Nov. 6. Declining issues outnumbered advances by more than 7 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 361 up, 1,289 down and 362 unchanged. Brokers said traders remained uneasy about the outlook for real-estate finance and regional banks after the Bank of New England on Friday announced projected increases in its loan-loss reserve and non-performing assets. In the past couple of weeks, Wall Street has been devoting increased attention to the soft real estate market in many parts of the country, and the problems real-estate debt might pose should prices of properties lag for an extended period. Some observers contend that the situation could become a primary contributing factor to a debt-induced business slump in 1990. Also, analysts said, traders began dumping stocks on fears that a yearend rally they had been anticipating might not materialize. Bank of New England shares led the active list, down 1{ at 7{ on the heels of a 3]-point drop Friday. Among other mortgage and regional banking issues, Citytrust Bancorp fell 2{ to 14|; Bank of Boston ~ to 16\; Shawmut National 1{ to 17~; First Interstate Bancorp 4] to 43[; Federal National Mortgage 2| to 31[, and Federal Home Loan Mortgage 5~ to 61~. The money-center bank group also came under selling pressure. Bankamerica dropped 2[ to 23~; Chemical Banking 2 to 29\; Manufacturers Hanover 1~ to 31], and Chase Manhattan 1[ to 31~. Losers among the blue-chip industrials included International Business Machines, down 1] at 93|; American Telephone & Telegraph, down } at 46; USX, down } at 34[, and McDonald's, down ] at 33~. Marriott dropped 1 to 33|. The company announced a restructuring program, including a planned move out of the fast-food and family restaurant business, but also estimated lower fourth-quarter earnings. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 184.79 million shares, down from 240.39 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 223.24 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $57.74 billion, or 1.71 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped 3.28 to 190.17. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 6.21 to 393.60, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down 6.37 at 343.77. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market tumbled 7.81 to 436.03. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 370.86, down 4.64.
